newsitem.title: GERMANY: Industrial oilseeds losing importance - German firm.
newsitem.headline: Industrial oilseeds losing importance - German firm.

text.p: Marketing problems and declining land-set aside have lessened the role of oilseeds crops grown for industrial purposes, German crusher Oelmuehle Hamburg AG said on Wednesday.
"Farmers are losing interest in growing industrial crops and sales of oils for non-food uses are developing more slowly than hoped," Oelmuehle chairman Arnd von Wissel told a shareholders meeting.
The EU Farm Council in July reduced the land set-aside rate for the 1997 harvest to five percent from 10, 12 and 15 percent respectively in the most recent campaigns.
This will release an estimated seven to eight million tonnes of grain on to the market.
But under U.S./EU agreements, the oilseeds area for food and animal feed purposes is permanently fixed at 5.48 million hectares, from which 10 percent set-aside is deducted.
The agreements also allow production of one million ha worth of seeds where the oils are restricted to industrial applications.
Von Wissel said the EU had nearly reached that limit in 1995, with Germany alone accounting for 330,000 ha.
But farmers were now likely to focus on additional arable areas to grow lucrative grain and traditional oilseeds crops.

Rapeseed oil used in alternative car fuels was uncompetitive versus oil from fossil fuels, farmers were receiving less compensation for idling land and the bureaucracey surrounding biodiesel was too costly.
The oilseeds lobby UFOP, which promotes rape oil in fuel, oleochemical and hydraulics industry uses, has estimated the industrial rapeseed area this year will be down by 16 percent.
Von Wissel said biofuel sales volumes were not strong enough to support a number of specialised crushing plants.
Only one out of three planned biofuel projects -- Oelmuehle Leer Connemann GmbH near the Dutch/German border with an annual capacity of 80,000 tonnes -- had come on stream, in April 1996.
